revisions.*: {{about|the 13th-century logician and author of medical works|the Dominican friar|Petrus Ferrandi Hispanus|information on the pope often identified with the author|Pope John XXI}} [[File:Summulae logicales.jpg|thumb|Frontispiece of work by Peter of Spain]] __NOTOC__ '''Peter of Spain''' ({{lang-la|Petrus Hispanus}}; [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and {{lang-es|Pedro Hispano}}; {{floruit|13th}} century) was the author of the ''{{lang|la|Tractatus}}'', later known as the ''{{lang|la|Summulae Logicales}}'', an important [[medieval]] [[medieval university|university]] textbook on [[Aristotelian logic]]. As the Latin ''[[Hispania]]'' was considered to include the entire [[Iberian peninsula]], he is traditionally and usually identified with the [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] scholar and ecclesiastic Peter Juliani, who was elected [[Pope John XXI]] in 1276.Michael Haren, ''Medieval Thought'' (1985), p.148.For a more recent defense of the identity between Petrus Hispanus and Pope John XXI, see the preface of W. Degen and B Bapst (2006), ''Logische Abhandlungen'', Munich. The identification is sometimes disputed, usually by [[Spanish people|Spanish]] authors, who claim the author of the ''{{lang|la|Tractatus}}'' was a [[Castilian people|Castilian]] [[Dominican Order|Blackfriar]]. He is also sometimes identified as [[Petrus Ferrandi Hispanus]] ({{abbr|d.|died}} 1254 {{abbr|x|sometime between}} 1259). {{anchor|Biography|History}} ==Life== {{see also|Pope John XXI}} The author of the ''{{lang|la|Tractatus}}'' is assumed to have studied under [[John Pagus]]. ==Philosophical works== There are a large volume of manuscripts and printed editions of the ''{{lang|la|Summulae Logicales}}'', indicative of its great success throughout [[Europe]]an universities well into the seventeenth century. Peter of Spain supported an investigation of teaching at the University of Paris which resulted in the [[bishop of Paris|Parisian bishop]]'s [[Condemnation of 1277]], which denounced Aristotelian propositions which conflicted with [[dogma|church doctrine]].Principe, Lawrence M. (2002) History of Science: Antiquity to 1700. Lecture 19. The Teaching Company, Chantilly, VA) :''Dialectica est ars artium, scientia scientiarum, ad omnium methodorum principia viam habens; sola enim dialectica probabiliter disputat de principiis omnium aliarum scientiarum, et ideo in acquisitione omnium aliarum scientiarum dialectica debet esse prior.'' "Dialectic [that is, logic, in Peter's terminology] is the art of arts, science of sciences, having the way to the principles of all methods; for in fact dialectic alone credibly argues about the principles of all other sciences, and therefore in [one's] acquisition (learning) of all other sciences dialectic must be prior." — Peter of Spain.As quoted, for instance, in ''[http://books.google.com/books?id=etJhAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA2-PA131 Papst Johannes XXI]'' by Stapper, Richard, [http://books.google.com/books?id=etJhAAAAMAAJ&pg=RA3-PA5&dq=est+ars+artium p. 5], collected in ''Kirchengeschichtliche Studien'' v. 4. ==Medical works== [[File:Thesaurus pauperum V00179 00000004.tif|thumb|''Thesaurus pauperum'']] A Petrus Hispanus, usually identified as the same scholar,Spruyt, Joke (2001), "Peter of Spain", ''Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy''. Revised 2007. [http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/peter-spain/ Eprint]. was also credited as the author of a ''Commentary on Isaac'', one of the foundational texts of [[clinical pharmacology]]. A Pedro Hispano was also credited with the ''Treasury of the Poor'' (''{{lang|la|Thesaurus Pauperum}}''), a comprehensive recipe book for contraception and inducement of menstruation. Many of Peter’s recipes have been found to be surprisingly effective by contemporary research, and it is believed that women in antiquity had more control over their reproduction than previously believed.John M. Riddle, ''Contraception and Abortion from the Ancient World to the Renaissance'', Harvard University Press, 1994. ==English translation== * ''Peter of Spain Summaries of Logic'', Text, Translation, Introduction, and Notes by Brian P.
